I‚Äôve been pounding the table about the potential of deregulation for a little while now. That‚Äôs why The Free Markets ETF $FMKT has GE Vernova $GEV as one of its core holdings. This clean energy powerhouse is positioned to potentially capitalize on Trump‚Äôs deregulation agenda. üßµ

For a full list of fund holdings and more information on FMKT, please visit freemarketsetf.com. Lead-Lag Publishing, LLC is not an affiliate of Tidal/Toroso, Tactical Rotation Management, LLC, SYKON Capital, Point Bridge Capital, LLC or ACA/Foreside

Overall, I think it comes down to what you believe will happen with deregulation. If the administration continues to make it a priority, $GEV offers a compelling investment case. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs a core holding in $FMKT. The energy transition meets free market principles.

This sector has been largely directionless for a while, even throughout the Liberation Day pivot to defense. But with so much struggle to push through tariffs, I think deregulation may become the ultimate calling card that finally works - with $GEV as a prime beneficiary.

The numbers are telling: $GEV projects 6.4% sales growth for 2025 and 10% for 2026. Yes, they trade at a premium, but I think deregulation upside potential justifies the valuation if conditions align.

Given how $GEV is positioned at the intersection of grid modernization, nuclear innovation, and domestic manufacturing, I don‚Äôt think we can ignore what this investment is telling us about where $FMKT sees opportunity in the evolving regulatory landscape.

The story here is $GEV‚Äôs nuclear small modular reactor program. Their BWRX-300 SMR is scheduled for commissioning in Canada by 2029, with partnerships expanding globally. The administration‚Äôs pro-nuclear stance makes this perhaps their most compelling growth catalyst.

If we get further energy deregulation, it could be another big tailwind for $GEV and ultimately $FMKT. Their technologies already produce over half the power in the United States, and simplified permitting would accelerate deployment timelines.

I think there‚Äôs a case that $GEV has some real potential here if deregulation conditions fall into place. Their grid solutions factory in Pennsylvania is getting an $80M upgrade, creating American jobs while modernizing critical infrastructure. Liberation Day economics at work.

The fact that the markets have started shaking off tariff and trade policy volatility may create an opportunity for $GEV to drift higher. Their investment in U.S. manufacturing shows they‚Äôre betting big on American energy revival - a key theme for the administration.

When I say $GEV is a standout opportunity, I‚Äôm looking at their remarkable stock surge over the past year. This isn‚Äôt just momentum - it‚Äôs the market recognizing a company with strategic positioning across multiple energy technologies ready to potentially benefit from regulatory relief.
At a bare minimum, I recommend deregulated food stocks for $FMKT even if you choose to continue to not eat.
